### 🌿 **Why use Norwegian eco-slang?**

1. **Local authenticity**

In a city like Bergen, where people are proud of their culture and environment, this can be a strong signal that you're **part of the scene**, not just passing through.

2. **Emotional connection**  
   Slang can be more **fun**, **relatable**, and **memorable**. It can help you stand out in a pop-up setting where visual and emotional impact matter.

3. **Niche appeal**  
   If your brand is eco-conscious and you're targeting a younger, more socially aware demographic, using eco-slang can help you **speak their language** and build a stronger connection.

4. **Social media buzz**  
   If you're planning to promote the pop-up on Norwegian social media or with influencers, using local eco-slang can help the content **resonate more locally** and **go viral in the right circles**.

---

### 🐢 **Why *not* use Norwegian eco-slang?**

1. **It might not be widely understood**  
   Slang, especially eco-slang, can be **niche or regional**, and may not be understood by everyone — even Norwegians. If your pop-up is open to a **broad audience**, English might be more accessible.

2. **It’s extra work**  
   If you’re already tight on time or resources, the **effort vs. reward** might not be worth it. English is **globally understood**, and many Norwegians are fluent in English anyway.

3. **You might get it wrong**  
   Slang can be **slippery** — a word might be misunderstood, or worse, **offensive**. You don’t want to accidentally use a term that’s outdated or has a different connotation.

---

#### 🐰 **More playful / slangy eco terms**

Ask yourself:

- **Who is the audience?**  
  If it's mostly young, local, and eco-conscious, then yes — eco-slang can help you **stand out and build rapport**.

- **Is it for the visuals or the captions?**  
  If it's for the **visuals**, a few Norwegian terms can add **flavor and authenticity** without overwhelming anyone.

- **Are you going to be on social media?**

## 🧭 **Step 1: Do You Need a Google Business Profile?**

✅ **Yes**, you **do need a Google Business Profile** (formerly Google My Business) to **add events** to Google Maps — but it doesn’t have to be for a physical store or permanent business.

You can create a **Google Business Profile** for your **brand or event**, even if it’s temporary.

---

## 🛠️ **Step 2: Create a Google Business Profile (if you don’t have one)**

1. Go to: [https://www.google.com/business](https://www.google.com/business)
2. Sign in with your Google account.
3. Click **"Create a listing"**.
4. Choose **"Business or service"**.
5. Fill in the basic info:
   - **Name**: Your brand name or pop-up name (e.g., “EcoPop Bergen”)
   - **Category**: Choose something like “Pop-up shop”, “Event space”, or “Retail store”
   - **Address**: The **exact address** of your pop-up (even if it’s temporary)
   - **Phone number**: Optional, but helpful
   - **Website**: If you have one, include it
6. Submit for **verification** (you’ll get a postcard or phone call within a few days)

> ⚠️ **Note**: If the pop-up is at a **third-party space** (like a rented store), you can still list it under your brand. Just be accurate with the address.

---

## 🗓️ **Step 3: Add the Event to Your Google Business Profile**

Once your Google Business Profile is verified, you can **add events**.

1. Go to [Google Business Profile](https://business.google.com/)
2. Select your listing
3. Click **"Info"** > **"Add more info"** > **"Events"**
4. Click **"Add event"**
5. Fill in the event details:
   - **Event name** (e.g., “EcoPop Bergen – Zero Waste Pop-Up”)
   - **Start and end dates/times**
   - **Address** (must match the one on your Google Business Profile)
   - **Description** (keep it short and catchy)
   - **Website link** (optional)
   - **Event category** (e.g., “Retail”, “Food & Drink”, “Sustainability”)
6. Click **"Save"**

---

## 🌐 **Step 4: Your Event Will Appear on Google Maps & Google Search**

- Once the event is added, it will show up:
  - On **Google Maps** when people search for “events in Bergen”
  - On **Google Search** when people search for “events near me”
  - In **Google’s “Things to Do”** tab (especially if your event is upcoming and local)

---

## 🔄 **Step 5: Update or Remove the Event After the Pop-Up**

- You can **edit or delete** the event from your Google Business Profile at any time.
- If you’re done with the event, just remove it so people don’t see it as an active listing.

---

## 🚫 **What You Can’t Do (for now)**

- You **can’t submit a pop-up event without a Google Business Profile**.
- You **can’t submit a pop-up as a one-off event** via the Google Maps "Suggest an edit" tool (unless it’s at an existing business location).

---

## ✅ **Pro Tips for Better Visibility**

- **Use keywords** like “eco”, “sustainable”, “zero waste” in your event name and description.
- **Include high-quality images** of your pop-up in your Google Business Profile.
- **Encourage attendees to check in** and **leave a review** — this boosts your listing.
- **Post the event on your socials** with a **link to the Google Maps listing**.

---

## 🧪 **Example Link Format**

You can also create a **custom Google Maps link** to your event using Google’s **"Share"** feature in the Google Business Profile.

Example:
```
https://maps.google.com/?cid=1234567890123456789
```

You can include this in your **social media posts**, **email invites**, and **local ads**.
